those characters in different parts of their fabric; thus showing that
no lines of demarcation can be drawn across any part of the series, that
shall definitely separate it any number of groups, each characterised
by features entirely peculiar to itself. Thus, then, we see that the
real relationships of the different types to each other, can only be
determined by <u>the careful comparison of a very large number
of individuals obtained from as many different sources as possible</u>;-
a process which is too frequently neglected by Systematists, many
of whom erect species, and even genera, without the least
care to determine by any such process, the real value of the distinctions by which
they characterise them.

73  The right mode of proceeding in every other department of
Natural History, must be that which has thus been proved to be
the only reliable method in this; and I venture, therefore, to lay
down the following general Canons; deduced from the preceding
history; which<s>,</s> will, I think, be found accordant with the experience
of all soundly-judging Naturalists, although they have not
yet, so far as I am aware, received a formal expression.
